div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: DRAINAGE IN EGYPT.
div.p: The report of the Department of Public Health for 1905 contains a subject of considerable interest to the general public, viz., the drainage of Cairo and Port Said. The question deserves to be followed with attention by the European colony of the two cities, and we hope that State expenditure on drainage schemes will meet with no opposition on their part. At present Cairo is without a proper system of drainage, and the subsoil, in consequence both of this foot and the greater quantity of water now employed, is being rapidly contaminated by sewage infiltration. The town is spreading so rapidly and land values are now so high that practically every square metre is either built over or reserved for building, and in nearly all the new constructions there exists no place outside the actual buildings for the disposal of sewage, which is generally collected in pits sunk beneath the entrance hall or the central court, round which a square block of perhaps four or five stories has been erected. Quite apart from the discomfort and inconvenience of this practice, it stands to reason that the soil below and immediately around these buildings must be fooled by even the slightest accumulation of sewage unless the pits are absolutely water-tight, a condition which, we imagine, is not fulfilled in a goodly proportion even of the newest buildings in Cairo.

In Port Said the conditions are even worse. Sir Horace Pinching has the following observations to make on the subject "Immediately a town possesses an ample supply of water, a much larger quantity is used, and pari passu a larger amount of sewage matter is the result. The consequence of all this greater consumption of water is that the cesspools fill rapidly, and the earth is unable to absorb all the sewage matter which is being poured into it, and a time will come when the Government will have to consider the necessity of providing a system of drainage for some of the more important towns of Egypt. The necessity for the drainage of Port Said is, in my opinion, as pressing as that of Cairo. The subsoil water in this town is within half a metre of the surface, and many of the cellars and underground apartments are constantly awash with sewage matter which is continually oozing out from the adjacent cesspools. Port Said, like Cairo, has increased in size very considerably of late years and has every prospect of becoming a very important town. It is therefore all the more necessary to com- mence a drainage scheme at once, and extend it as the town increases; the longer it is delayed the more expensive will the scheme become. Port said being built on level gound, the sewage cannot be . removed from the town by gravitation sewers, bat will have to he drawn out by suction pump or forced out; some scheme will, I presume, be adopted which has been. found to work satisfactorily in other towns built under similar conditions."

In Cairo the approaching arrival of a dis-tinguished Anglo-Indian drainage specialist to study the various schemes submitted to the Government and to select the one be considers most suitable, is of good omen, and we cordially agree with Sir Horace Pinching in hoping that the Government will take the matter up seriously and carry out a scheme to completion. Otherwise there is every risk of an epidemic—and a serioas epidemic, too— inflicting great loss on the ooantry. Imagine the results of an outbreak of typhoid fever on a large scale at the beginning of the tourist season ! Quite apart from the regrettable loss of life the country woald be financially the worse. There would be an exodus of those who had arrived for the winter, arrangements would he cancelled right and left, in- flicting grave loss on the hotels and the nameroas interests dependent on them, and while we might not regret the pecuniary damage doce to donkey-boys and their kind we should have to face the fact that two or three winters would have to pass before Cairo regained its fair fame as a health resort "Give a dog a had name and it is snre to stick to him," is a proverb that applies to tourist resorts as well as to men and beasts.

Finally, we with great pleasure note Sir Horace Pinohing's pithy expression of opinion on the projeot for depriving the European quarter of Cairo of its only lung: "With regard to the necessity of in future leaving open spaces in the town to act as longs to the city, I may mention the suggestion which has been made to oonstraot the new Opera House in the Esbekieh Gardens. I cannot think that the Government would be so ill advised as to entertain snob a suggestion; the Esbekieh Gardens is the only open space left in this quarter of the oity, and to fill it up partially by a large Opera House would in my opinion be absolutely unjustifiable."

div.p: Today's plague bulletin records a fresh case at Alexandria, that of a young Armenian living in the Attario. A fatal case is also reported from Saez, and one of the patients at Alexandria was discharged as cored.

Saint Sacns, and which has not been heard before in Alexandria. The Bracale orchestra will be composed of fifty musicians.

div.head: Prize Distribution.
div.p: The annual distribution of prizes at the College' Saint Loois, Rosetta-avenne, will take place to-morrow at 4.30 p.m., under the presidency of M. Albert Revelli, French Vice\ Consol. The programme to be eaaoted by thepnpils includes an English farce in one aot, "Doctor Diaoulum," and a French operetta, "Les Dix Ans de Louis XV.'' There are besides several reoitationa and dialogues in both French and English.

div.head: Alhambra Theatre.
div.p: The stay of Castellano's opera company at the Alhambra camo to a close yesterday evening with a performance of La lioHvme. To-morrow the boards of the theatre will be oooupied by an Italian dramatic company under the direction of Sig. Giovanni Novelli, an artist who has made a ramefor himself on the Italian stage. He is ably supported by Signa. Lina Vidaly and an excellent oompany, which has obtained a good deal of Bucoess in Cairo.

div.head: Murder
div.p: The enquiry into the cause of death of the Maltese woman living in Clot Bey street, Cairo which we reported yesterday, casts considerable suspicion on two natives whose occupation furnish the spoken Arabic of Egypt with one of its favourite terms of abuse. The men lived in the house of their victim, whose reputation—it may be added—was none of the best. Theft is believed to have been the motive of the crime, no money having been found in the house of the murdered woman.

div.head: Boating Fatality.
div.p: Two men lost their lives on Saturday by the capsizing of a boat in Lake Timsab, near Suez. There were 18 men in the boat at the time, and they were proceeding to the Suez Canal Company's works, where they are employed. The disaster might have been greater had not M. Sanpriere, an official of the Suez Canal Company, happened to pass at the time on board a steam launch. Realising the danger he called for assistance by means of the steam whistle, and, the company's boats appearing on the scene, 16 men were saved.

div.head: Fishing Boat Disaster.
div.p: The unfortunate victims of the fishing boat disaster off the Aboukir ooast last Monday night are still under water, the efforts of the divers employed by the Italian consular authorities to recover their bodies having proved unavailing. The corpses of the seamen are encased in the ill-fated vessel, hence the difficulty in bringing the bodies to the surface. It is thought that the only means of recovering the bodies wi'i - '1 . tiop but redoubled eh --' - /"ba arid* i-i by by a fresh • •* div io re-over the b«. dies without resorting to this expedient.

div.head: St. Andrew's Girls Upper School.
div.p: The annual exhibition and distribution of prizes took place in this school yesterday, Rev. H. P. Reid occupying the chair. The programme, which consisted of a cantata, "Queen of the Seasons," and two scenes from "Les Femmes Savantes." was heartily applauded by a large gathering of parents and friends. The prizes were presented by Mrs. Reid. Amongst the successful pupils we particularly noted Lilly Faggy, winner of the Scripture medal annually given by Major Allan, and Misses Simana and Draycott, who shared the special prize for "good conduct." An exhibition of needlework, drawing, and painting showed that careful attention had also been given to these branches of school-work throughout the year.

div.head: THE TABAH DISPUTE. EVENTS AT AKABA.
div.p: The following summary of the events that took place in the Akaba district between January 1 and May 13 of the cu'rert year may interest those of our readers who have not had the opportunity of studying the Correspondence just issued.

In the middle of January complaints of Egyptian encroachments on Turkish territory are brought to Sir N. O'Conor by the Porte. Meantime rumours of Turki.-h encroachments reach the Egyptian Government.

Jan. 15.—Lord Cromer suggests delimitation. Mr. Brandy is sent to occupy Tabah, the Nekl-el Afcaba, and El Gattsr, but finds Tabah in Turkish hands. The ganboat NourCl-Bahr being unable to land men without provoking a collision, G ziret Faroun is occupied by an Egyptian detachment under Saad Bey Rifaat.
Jan. 29*—Rushdi Pasha. Governor of Akaba, summons Saad Bey to evacuate the Island. The garrison of Akaba hiving been meantime El Gattar and
Feb. 14.—H.M.S. Diana ordered to proceed from Suez to Akaba. Lord Cromer gives the following accoant of her mission and sob- sequent events :—

"I received a report from Captain Phipps Hornby, stating that, on the arrival of the Diana off Akaba, Rushdi Pasha bad prepared to resist a landing and had sent his troops (between 3,0( 0 and 4,000 men) to their fighting stations. Captain Hornby, however, got into communication with Rnshdi Pasha, and soon succeeded in establishing friendly relations. He is, nevertheless, convinced that Rjahdi Pasha—who appears to be a fne specimen of the fighting type of Turkish officer- meant to defend the place to the bitter end if he bad been attacked.

"I cannot donbt that Captain Hornby's opinion on this subject is pertaotly correct as not only on this occasion, but on the first arrival of-the Nnr-el-Bahr at Taba, and subsequently when IDs Msjesty's ship Minerva visited Rafoh, the TnrkUh troops openly prepared to repel by force any attempt to land men.

"I take this,opportunity of placing on record my high appreciation cf the invariable tact di-played by Captain Hornby in relations with the Tarki.h authorities at Akaba, and of the great assistance which I have derived from his clear and exhaustive Reports. His Majesty's fhip Diaca had a long, and tedious watch of over three months in the Gulf of good service in preventing the Turki from extending their encroachments, and from thus rendering a friendly settlement more difficult.
"All hopes of a speedy settlement now centred in the Joint Commission.

"The Turkish Commissioners proceeded from the Cairo^ station straight to the house of Moukhtar Pasha, and remained there for a week without oommunioating either with any Egyptian Government official or with His Majesty's Agency.
"They finally loft C *iro in plain clothes by an early train, and embarked for Beyrout en route,.At was said, for Akaba.
"It is difficult to guess the\true reason of this extraordinary behaviour on the part of ritiea 'Joiut' Commission was therefore abandoned.
"The Khedive was absent on a trip in the desert during the stay of the Turkish Commissioners in Cairo, bat on his return His Highness assure! me thU no communication had reachod him from them.

"About the middle of March Mr. Bramly reported that two Badpnin Sheiks, n had gone over to the Turki. I merely mention the poin1-, as their evi fence will probably bo forthcoming on the Turkish side when 'tribal limits are discussed.
After this the status quo near Akaba remains unaltered except for the arrival of Turkish reinforcements till May 13, on which date Tabah is evacuated. resortiuf to thia expedient.

div.head: A RECLAME FROM THE SCHOOLS- "EGYPT'S MIRABEAU."
div.p: One of the native scholars belonging to the High Schools Club, Cairo, writes to "Al Lewa" as follows on bahalt of his comrades :

"I am authorised by some of my fellow- scholars to write and say to you that thet j Egyptian onpils of the High 8chools—the flower of Egypt—quite believe that, if there is I a man in Egypt, full of vivid feeling, who aims 1 wth the utmost zsal at the benefit of bis 1 country, and does his test—with heart and ' tongue—for the welfare of the land, that man i is undoubtedly Mustapha Pasha Kamel. We scholars regard him with admiration and esteem, and be is in oor opinion equal to thellnngarisn Kossuth, the I'alian Garibaldi, or the French Mirabeau. It is an honourable fo ition for Mus tapha Pasha lo be qual fisd as ' being far above the mass of Egyptians/No wt nder then if "Al Mokattam" states that the Ulema of Al Azhar University, the notable', and the popils of the High Schools of Biypt' are parfootly content to accept Mustapha Paths Kamel as the bead of the Nationalist party.

div.head: ANOTHER TURKISH INTRIGUE. TRIPOLI FRONTIER MOVEMENT RAISES FRENCH SUSPICIONS-
div.p: Pan Islamism continues to cause the French uneasiness. Simultaneously with the attempted seizure of Egyptian territory by the Saltan of Tnrkey, a force of Turkish troops was sent to a place about 80 miles sooth-west of the western frontier of Tripoli, near Ghat. This force, however, did not reach its destination, as the resalt of the British negotiations with Turkey over the Bgyptian boundary made the Tnrkrsh commander in Tripoli very cautions.

At the beginning of July, however (says the "Daily Mail's" Tanis correspondent), another move was made, and a battalion of Turkish infantry with two gnns started ; but on arrival found French troops in possession. Rejeb Pasha, who oommanded the force, was not disposed to oreate trouble with France, and wisely withdrew.

The French prepared an expedition in haste at Berrezof in Tonis, and moved ont to rein- foroe their small column at Ghat. The mling chief of the tribes at Azghar, near Ghat, complained of the French occupation, and demanded Turkish protection ; bat on a meeting being held beween Rejeb Pasha and the French Commander, the French olsimed that the tribes at Ghat and another place, called Janet, were under French protection.
The frontier line is uncertain, and the Franco-Turkish commission that met in 1893 to settle the boundaries of'Tunisia and Tripoli came to nothing.

div.head: 'ARE WE FANATICAL?" "ALMOAYAD'S" INTERVIEWS^
div.p: On boing interviewed by the representative of "Al-Moayad," Dr. Shibli Shmeil, a Syrian notable residing in Cairo, made the following statement: "Rsligione fanatioism does not really exist in Egypt, bat the natives of the lower olass are appallingly ignorant and the leaders of the nation extraordinarily hypocritical. The ignorant fellah is not naturally fana-tical, hot it might be said that the statements of those who deal in words are qoite capable of awakening in him something in the nature of hatted of foreigners. I consider (continued Dr. Shmeil) that the Denishwai people were treat ed very severely, but England, on the o'her hand, is not to be blamed for the precautionary measures she has taken. After 20 years' work of reform, which the Egyptians could not have dreamed of obtaining from any other Power, and after almost preferring the natives to the foreigners, whom the ooonpation had made within oertxin limits responsible for the welfare of the former, the British now fear that if they deem it proper to take strict measures for the preservation* of order in this country, the v alves would disagree with their project. The Denishwai penalties were very severe, but England was obliged to carry them out."

div.head: EX-OFFICER'S EXPLOITS.
div.p: A Cairo contemporary publishes a statement to whichwe should like to draw the attention of the authorities.

According to our contemporary, a Frenob boy of about 16 years of age entered an office in the Tewfikieh Rond-point on Saturday morning, leaving his sister to wait for a moment or two in the road. An ex officer of the Egyptian Army—whose name is given as Ahmed Eff. Fahmi Zaghlonl- who had followed the pair, now came up and behaved in a most indecent and improper manner towards the gi^J.

The brother, coming ont, found bis sister attempting to escape from the dutches of this satyr and told the ex officer, with appropriate comments, to unhand her. Zighlonl replied >y attacking the boy, whom he injared with iis umbrella, while a orowd of Moslems hosted and insulted these unfortunate children. A* hawish was compelled by 'some Europeans to nteriere and teak the ex officer and his viotim nto custody.

The young Frenchman, after vexatious delays, vas released and is about to make a complaint :o the consulate. If the faots aie in accordance with the above version we can only express our egret that no one was present to give the ex- officer a Bound thrashing for his pains.

div.head: HISTORY OF MOHAMEDAN CIVILISATION.
div.p: Geo'go Eff. Ziidan, proprietor of " Al-Hilal," who is one of the best-known Syrian anthers resident in Cairo, has published the fifth and last volume of his work entitled "Tarikh El- 'l'amaddun El Islami" (History of Mohamedan Civilisation) ;and tho Arab readers of Zoidan's series of historical novels will welcome the new and interesting work. In its style the book follows tho best new Arabio forms — being simple and at the same time well- oonetraoted and vigorous. It deals with social, political, geographical, and educational topics, comprising the system of Arab society, the class divisions that existed betore Islam, family life, the glory of the Caliphate, etc., eto. The author's erudition is manifested by the . fact that 130 Arabic, twelve English, aid six French works are cited in his notes and text.

div.head: THE "GREAT UNEMPLOYED. COMMENDABLE ACTION OF POLICE.
div.p: We are glad to note that the police are doing excellent work in clearing Alexandria of some of the unemployed Berbereen. These gentry, who idle in the streets, flock to an accident or a street fight with equal readiness, and played an active part in the December riots, form the most'dangerons element in the city. Tiny pnt np. at the expense of the European public, sleeping with the connivance ofbowabsand other servants in offices, outhouses, entrance balls, etc., where they commit occasional thefts and make night hideous with their olamonr.

By Egyptian law the Berberi who his been ..unemployed for 15 days, has no employment promised him, and no visible means of snbsis- tencs, is liable to arrest as a vagabond. Till recently this law has not been very strictly ehforced, bat the polioe have now taken up the campaign against these "maiterless men" with great vigour, and a number of Barabra idlers have been lodged in goal.

We need not say that mistakes are inevitable in all inch sweeping measures, and that a certain number of bontl fide servants have also found their way to the oaraool. They have, of ooorse, been released on famishing proofs of their identity; and we should like to remind their agJVieved employers—though we imagine that Done of • them take the temporary in-carceration of their servant as a personal grievance —that it is only fair to pardon a few mistakes on the part of the polioe in com sideration of the good they are doing in ridding ns of a crowd of useless and impudent idlers, who, we hopp, will be advised to return to Nubia as soon as they are released and devote their energies to agrionltnre or fishing—any employment in faot eave domeatio service.

div.head: CAIRO WATER SUPPLY.
div.p: In view of the objections recently made by a section of the public of Cairo to the water supplied by the Water Company from the artesian wells, and the report published by Dr. Bitter, the following extract from Sir Horace Pinching's excellent report on the work of the Pablio Health Department is of considerable interest :—

Complaints have been received as to the quality of the well water at present supplied by the company. The only complaint which in my opinion is grounded on fact, is that the nse of the water for washing clothes causes the linen to become yellow ; this is no donbt true, bat it is in no way due to the water, but to the faot that the Go vernment has obliged the company to raise the pressare io their pipes, aod, as many of these pipes have been in position for many years, the inside of them is coated with rust, partioles of which are detached by the increased pressare and carried away at the taps ; these partioles of iron in the water when used for washing linen oanse the yellow oolour (iron-monld). The oompany is taking steps to obviate this matter by washing ont the pipes under pressure and allowing the dirty water to ran to waste. I am informed that this inoonvenienoe is experienced in all towns at first where pressare is increased in old pipes.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Baron Werner von Griinan arrived at Alex andria yesterday by the 8.9. Hobenzollern and has taken over the duties of Garman Viofr Consol in this oity.
Harari Pasha and Cotta Bey, Secretary to the Connoil of Ministers, left for Earope yesterday.
Major J. H. L'Estrange Johnstone, R.E., general manager of the State Railways, goes on leave to-day for three months.
During Major Johnstone's absence, Capt. Bh kmey, R E, will act as general manager of the State Railways.

Rev. F. B. N. Norman-Lee, M.A., Chaplain to the Forces, has been granted sick leave on the Tsoommendation of a medical board for four month*. He will embark at Port Said on the P. & 0. S S, Mongolia to-day for passage home.

div.head: NEW WEEKLY MAIL SERVICE.
div.p: Larnaca, July 12.

At last it appears that Cyprus is to be linked up with the outer world by means of a regular weekly mail service. For several months she has been deprived of this inestimable boon, with a resulting inconvenience and loss of trade which has already been referred to in previous "Notes."

Rnmonr has naturally been bosy as to the arrangements which are to be made to enable Cyprus to carry on her growing export trade and afford facilities for passenger traffic. Sqb- jeot to certain conditions which have yet to be fulfilled, the contract is said to have been granted to the Limassol Steamship Company, which at present owns two small steamers, the Lefkosia and the Kypros, bat it is generally understood that another vessel is to be provided in the place of the latter.
Famagusta, Larnaca, and Limassol will be the regular ports of call, with monthly visits to Paphos, and the vessels will each week visit Port Said and Alexandria.
Shipping Facilities.

It never rains without pouring, and whereas for some time past we have been at the mercy of any stray vessel, we now have, in addition to the two above named beats, the British Asia> Minor Company's weekly Bteamer from Lar- naoa and Limassol to Egypt, and the Irini, a Greek vessel which calls regularly every 12 days. Her itinerary is Pincus, Alexandria, Limassol, Larnaca, Port Said, Alexandria, Piraeus. She is a capital little vessel of Eoglish build, and has accommodation for 40 first-class passengers. She also can take several second- cfaas passengers and a fair amonnt of cargo. She is a staunch, steady little oraft, and fairly fast, her appointments are good,and everything is dean and well foand. The food is appetizing and varied. The horrors of a crossing from Cyprus to Egypt now no longer exist, and what was formerly a martyrdom has now become a pleasure trip.
Export oT Mules.

The unmber of males exported from Cyprus is well maintained, and staunch, clean limbed, shapely animals they mostly are. They are generally slang on board with bate ropes,rather than with the canvas slangs, the objection to the latter apparently being that they are apt to slip round. If carefclly adjusted bafore hoist- ing, the ropes do not appear to oaass any dis oomfort9, and judging by the dooile bahavionr of the greater unmber of the animals daring and immediately after the, prooess of embarkation no cruelty is inflioted.
Chief Justice's Departure,

Sir Joseph Hutchinson, Chief Justice of Cypras, haB been appointed Chief Jastioe of Ceylon and is leaving almost immediately for England on leave previous to taking up his new duties. Sir Joseph and Lady Hutchinson will be very greatly missel by a large circle of friends in Cyprus. They have been resident there for eight years, daring which time they have been the oentre of the pleasantest aooial life cf the English community, and have been always to the fore in originating or aotively supporting every charitable movements for the benefit of the native poor. It is to be regretted that owing to the absence of most officials at Troodoa it will not be possible to give them the send-eff which they would otherwise have received.
Animal Show.

A successful Animal Show was held at Famagasta on the 25th Jane, when a good unmber of horses, moles, and donkeys were paraded apd prizes to the amonnt of abont £24 were awarded by the committee for the improvement of native stock. Those shows are doubtless of some n e in keeping alive the native interest in animal breeding, bat, as pointed out in previous Notes, no permanent and substantial benefit can accrue □nless and until the committee decide npon and publish tie standard of pointe to which in their well-considered opinion the varioos olasses of animals should conform. In other words, they shoulddi fine, for the information of breeders, what is to be considered as the true type, by which the judges will be governed in awarding prizes. Before any real advance can be made, the present fluid, anformed ideas as to what constitutes the perfect type of a Cypriot pony, male, donkey, etc., cow or other show animal, mast be crystallized, and this seems to be the first doty of the committee, and indeed its 'raison d'fltre.'
Ice Making.

The ice faotory at Larnaca is now a 'fait accompli,' and the first blocks of ice were tnrnrd out on the 8th inst. It is surprizing that this Island should so long have remained withoot this necessary commodity, and it is hoped that the venture now made will prove remunerative, and that it has come to stay.

div.head: THE MISSING LINK. ALEXANDRIA'S SHOPS.
div.p: Except for one or two establishments in the main thoroughfares, Alexandria's shops are not very imposing. Attractive Bhow windows—tbe secret of the retailer's suoceis—and even smart interiors are lacking. Much oould be done —especially daring the tourist season—to remedy this defeot. There is also no reason why, with the facilities afforded by eleotrio light, the shops could not open at night, and so obviate the weariness of shopping in the beat of the day. An attractive display, however, is the prime essential ; fsw people care to go into an unattraotive shop. A good restaurant of English cookery, where Oriental kickshaws shall be conspicuously absent, a first olass tea shop, and a proper toilet and lavoratory establishment would also make a difference.
Hyper-Commerclallsm.

In addition to material improvements, there is a social fault in our community which needs correcting, that of hyper-oommercialism. We are all ont here in this hot and dost? Eg^ut to make oor little pile in order thatwf mafie- tarn to the Motherland as sooraa positive Bat daring our sojourn it were n* jh rotter fir the common weal, were ther*> amongst, onrselves that co-operation whaoh. if^-he strength of the*other communion . If 'A.-Q- mercialism is for self, then it is a oet ?e, rather than a boon, and reaots in the ran on the individual. Our riches afford ns every opportunity for the sooial, intelleotnal, and artistio development of the community at large. So that we have no excuse for selfishness and caste distinctions.
Native Fine Art.

A sohool of fine art for the native population is another desideratum, oft hinted at by the painstaking fellaheen, whose mural decorations are the admiration of all Sight-seers. Some of these paintings in the out-of-the way suburbs are quaint and point to a certain sense of originality, Take, for instance, the paintings of a railway train on the white-washed walls of the Arab quarter of Chatby. Encouragement in this respect may lead to a revival of Arabesque art, on modern lines, to say nothing of railways.
Wanted—A British Monument.

The Anoients were wise, and endowed with much foresight, when they erected those Bplendid monuments which are the wonder of the world. What batter landmarks of history than, say, the Pyramids? We sooff at the vanity of the Pharaoh who erected unto Jiim- eelf so huge a tombstone, but was vani|f the ohjeot 1 No. The anoient lords of the Nile were philosophers who with keen prophetic vision foresaw that one day their kingdom would pass away, but rather than - its name should perish also, they wisely, if vainly, built enduring monuments and graved their biographies on immortal stone. But what memorial have we of our own occupation of Egypt 1 None, except the pen knife marks of tourists which disfigure many a noble slab. Britannia needs a monument also beside those of her predecessors. The colossal statne of thaLion Regardant—symbol of our might—set Up on the break-water of Alexandria Harbour is just the thing. Think how useful it would be to the Flinders-Petries of millennia ahead for identifying "the existence ot a prehistoric race of Northatn Barbarians— the Ioglizi—who held sway over this onoe- populons valley, until the Alemani drove them forth."
Our Flies.

What are we to do with the plague of flies? Some unkind person suggested exporting them and the Pyramid guides to Chicago. Bat radical measures such as these would do more harm than good. Think how the fly flicker trade would suffer, in the absence of Alias to fliok—and. this is ODS of our biggest industries. A somewhat ingenious remedy is electrocu-tion, performed by covering the walls with a conductive material which could be charged at intervale—before lnnoh say—the flies being attracted by a sweet and sticky preparation. Th°y could then be removed with a hatchet The carcases would make excellent fyrup, or enrrant bans, thus allowing of Egyptian competition with the Corinthian on'rant.
The High Cost of Living.

Wherever the Englishman goes, op go the prices ot everything. The saying is true of Egypt M of everywhere else. An old Egyptian Bey once told me that before the Occupation yon ccald for oue p;astre bay enough Vegetables to overa TQpm. How dees this tally with our present awful figures ? Of course it is all right for those who can efiord to pay, but what abont those who oD*t ? 1 don't approve of stinginess, but \inoline to the Greoian philosophy of "meAsare'in all things;" this was an inscription incised "into the eptabletnre of an ancient temple at Athens. It is a pity it was not copied at Karnak and Luxor, and wherever else the Britisher goes. The English tourist on his travels has an excellent reputation among the natives for his spending proclivities, but he has established a precedent which is hard for the permanent resident, who has to pay English prices for everything. The native expects it, and for the prestige of Qreat Britain's Dame we have tp relnotantly pay. The-faot wXh forcibly impressed npon my mind the other day when I went into a shop to effect a purchase. "The price is so mneb," said the mnrehant, "but as you are English, give doable." Wbat therefore we want in Egypt is the latter-day interpretation of the old To MESON ARISTON of the Greeks : PRIX MOD£R6S.
Fruit Market.

Under present conditions, an Arab fruit market is not the most agreeable of promenades for Europeans, what with dust, flits, and noxious smells. An innovation would be a "souk" pitched in the more European quarters, where ladies could buy their own fruit and vegetables, instead of delegating that function to servants, who, however faithful, are usually careless as to what Bort of frnit they bay. Thus, our ladies—bless their hearts! —could indulge in one of their most darling whims - that of marketing, and a slightly higher price would seonre to them the chmoest fruits. From a social point of view the gathering together of our wives and sisters on market days would afford them much pleasure. Charity bazaars are always a success; why not the real thing ?

div.head: LE SALAIRE DES EMPLOYES.>

J. H. L'E. JOHNSTONE.
Le Cairo, le ler Aoftt, 1906. 28270-2 2
Egyptian State Railways and Telegraphs
NOTICE.

The Egyptian State R tilwayt have the honour to inform the public that, to avoid overorowdiog of the Railway goods platforms daring the Cotton SeaeoD, and the oosfasion necessarily resulting therefrom, the following regulations will be enforced:—
"1—All consignments mast be separated from one another by a minimum distance of two feet.
'2—Consignments mast be well arranged and stacked together.

"8—When one lot of consignments has been received and stacked on one platform no more will be allowed tj be placed on that platform until there is vacant space, i.e., all stacking of subsequent consignments on the top of these already, existing will be prohibited.
"4 —A sufficient space must be left on each platform as a roadway for carts.

"Should the Railways find that these ar-rangements are not being carried out, and that there is confusion amongst the consignments,- notice is hefeby given that in such a case the gates of the station will be shut, and no more consignments will be accepted until the platforms are empty, and thereafter reoeipt will only be given for the amount of goods for which wagons are available each day.
' The Railways invite the oo-operation the publio in carrying out these regulations, which will avert the irregularities and oon- fnsion which arose at several stations daring the last Cotton Season.
Cairo, 1st Angast, 1906.
J. H. L'E. JOHNSTONE,
28270-2-2 General Manager.

div.head: TOWARDS THE NORTH POLE. MR WELLMAN'S EXPEDITION.

div.p: Mr

. Wellman has established communica- tion by wireless telegraphy from Danes Island, which is within 600 miles of the North Pole, to this place. The expedition hopes to start for the Pole in the middle of August. (Reuter)
The following Router's message was sent on Jaly 10 from DanSs Island (vid Digernnlen, Jaly 17)

The Wellman expedition steamer "Frithjof" arrived here last night after a quiok voyage from Tromtii. The shore of Virgo Bay is covered with structures and material. Another cargo is expected in a few days. Engineer Liwentaal has finished the best house ever built in the Arotio regions, with scientific ventilation, a bath-tab, and machine shops ready for work. He is starting a giant house for the balloon. Mr. Wellman says that the outlook is favourable. Notwithstanding the magnitude of the operation a continental newspaper has chartered a steamship and sent a special correspondent and artist here to report the doings of the expedition. Mr. Wellman hopes to establish - wireless communication with Hammerle8t in ten days* time.. .This message is sent by express steamer to —-dvent Bay, where it will connect with a German tourist ship. Mr. Wellman's camp looks like a new town in the colonies. All the twenty-four men are well.

600 members of the Parliaments of Europe and America assembled to day in the Golden Gallery of the House of Lords in order to discuss questions of peace atad arbitration. Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman, welcoming the conference, expressed the King's and Govern-ment's sympathies with the objects in view. He especially greeted the members of the Dama, exolaiming "The Duma is dead, long live the Doma," which sraa received with cheering.

div.head: DISSOLUTION OF DUMA. CONDEMNED BY PRESS.

div.p: It is announced that the members of the Duma are returning immediately to Russia in order to join in the struggle.
The English and European Press are unani-mous in condemning the dissolution of the Duma as ill-oonsidered, unjustifiable, and ruinous.
There is a heavy fall io Russian shares. (B.)
The majority cf fchs memb>_: fthe Duma have gone to V -its:' Massing the manifesto.
The c-ty is qc-.st. Troops and police are everywhere. Mc-"y expulsions have taken place. Several papers have been suppressed.
One hundred and eighty five deputies of the Dama met daring the night at Viborg and voted a manifesto oalling upon the people to refuse to pay taxes and to serve in the army. ( Havas)

div.head: TROUBLE IN ARABIA.
div.p: M.Cheradame publishes in the onnent num-ber of the "Energie Practise," a letter from Muscat, dated June 15, under the beading "A Decisive 8'ep Towards Independence." This letter purports to give pait'oalars of "an event of extreme gravity, which has not yet attracted the attention of the European Pres-," though brief mention was made ofitina Cairo telegram published in ",rheTimea"of May 14. The event is the defeat, on April 12 last, of the Saltan's adherent Abdul Az'S Ibn Rashid by the party of independence under the leadership of Abdul Az:z Ibn Saond. The latter, by anight march, surprised and rooted his enemy north of Kas- »im, killing Ibn Rashid himself as well as a large number of the leading notables of Hai', his capital. Ibn Saoud immediately despatched messengers to his friend the Sheikh of KowaU, with the seal ring ot Ibn Rashid which bad bteo taken from the body. The news spead rapidly, causing great exoitementthroughout the whole country. It extended even to the small Arab colony in Bombay. It hassincebren ascertained that the son and successor of Ibn Rashid sent a deputation t> Kuwait requesting lb? sheikh to submit proposals of peace on his behdf to Ibn Saoud. According to the writer of the letter, it is expected that the Shaikh of Kuwait will do his utmost to promote peace in' order to counterbalance the piwer of Ion Saoud, who might otherwise become stronger than himself

div.head: THE SINAI DISPUTE.
div.p: LORD CROMER'S LUCID REPORT. OPINIONS OF THE PRESS.

Unanimous praise is bestowed upon Lord Cromer by the home presR for his clear and in-terest! ng statement on theSinaifront;er negotia tions, in the White Paper published last week, and satinfaction is expressed at the snocess of British diplomacy.
The following area few cf the comments on the subjeot:—
"STANDARD."
Seldom has a more interesting and sng- geative document been issued by tW Foreign Office than tho Correspondence, published yes-terday, respecting the Tnrco Egyptian Frontier in the 3inai Peninsula

It is plain that the patience of the British Government was strained almost beyond endnrance. Up to the last moment of the period fix id by oar ultimatum, and even beyond it, the Porte employed every artifice' of diplomatic cbioarery which might delay the inevitable surrender. The only exonse for the condnot of Turkey in seeking to ignore the plain terms of the delimitation settled in 1892, on the accession of Abbas Pasha, is that reports had been sent from Cairo to Constantinople— wb are they seem to have been believed—to the effect that the^ Egyptian Government intended to erect fortifications on the frontier, which would be used as a basis for interference with the Hadjaz Railway. There was no foundation in fact for the malioions rumour invented by the Pan-Islamio Press, and the Saltan, if he pleased, coaid easily have assured himself of the true character of Mr.Bramly's instructions. The fiction was, howevor, seized upon and exploited. With suoh obstinacy was the dispate oondaoted by the Porte that the situation was not relieved until orders had been given for a material reinforcement of the British garrison in Egypt and for the mobilisation of the'British Fie 3t under Lord Charles Beresford.
"MORNING POST/'

The Correspondence shows that the nation is indebted to Sir E. Grey, the Earl of Cromer, and Sir N. O'Conor for a diplomatic suocess won by. a resolute attitude following upon exemplary forbearance. It proves, what was already suspected, that this success was achieved only at the eleventh honr. under pressure of a naval and military display oalon- lated to convince the .Porte that we considered the point at issne to be vital;* and Sir E. Grey is shown adroitly seizing the oooasion to dismiss any donbts entertained at Constantinople, or elsewhere, as to our position in Bgypt as oivil advisers and military proteotors of the Khedivate. Unless Tarkey should again bo BO misled as to try to foroe our hands, it will hardly bo necessary to give any olearer declaration of our attitude towards Ottoman suzerainty than that quoted by Lord Cromer from a dispatch of Sir E. Grey. . . It Will be noted with satisfaction that Lord Cromer's remedy for the onrest so industriously fanned by a gutter press, and from quarters of much higher respectability in touch with the enemies of Great Britain, is to advocate a permanent iuorease of the British garrison, the cost of which unfortunately, hot with justice, must fall on the Egyptian Treasury

It is to le hoped tty the lesson will not be lo3t upon the fanatioal wire pullers, in Cairo and Alexandria, and that a perusal of the correspondence now published will convince them of the futility of their attempts to undermine our authority or destroy our work in Egypt.
TRIBUNE.''

Papers issued yesterday tell the story of the Tabah negotiations with a clearness and a skill in narrative which mark, we hope, a new departure in the editing of cfRoial publications Historically they have their value as a competent record of a carious and interesting episode, bat the affair in all probability is doted, and" nothing more need be said of it save that these documents confirm the universal opinion that Sir Edward Grey conducted an incident which was certainly grave and might have become threatening with tact, with firmness, and, above all, with success.
"GLOBE."

By f»r the most interesting and impressive portion of the correspondence is contained in the summary given by Lord Cromer of the effect prodneed in Egypt by the controversy, aud of the feelings which it evoked among the Moslem population of that conntry. Since that dispatch was penned the tragedy at Denishwai has given a most striking and painful weight to his Lordship's forecast. A wave of unrest is passing tv.r the native mind in Egypt,and the appeals to religions fanatioism ottered in the vernacular Press and elsewhere have fallen upon soil which is only too reoeplive. . . ,

Of the instigators of those appeals Lord Cromer speaks in very foroible language. He entertains no doubt that the seditions writings in tho Pan Islemic newspapers have bern encouraged by many persons both insido and outside Egypt ; and he intimites that if in consequence of these incitements, any section of the public were to pass from words to deod", and public trarquiHity were to become seriously menaced, he would net shrink from measures of repression.
"MANCHESTER GUARDIAN."

It is a thousand pities that any party in Egjpt should look towards Turkey, which has always been a curse to the land. But a wholesome sentiment will always drive ont unwholesome sentiment, whioh, indeed, has power only over political souls drained dry of the generous natural juices and secretions. If the pro-Turkish party has any real hold on Egypt, it is because there is no real feeling of Egyptian nationality ; and if Lord Cromer wishes for safeguards against the pan-Islamic movement, lie will find them by awakening a sense of national pride in Egypt. He needs to ronse a healthy sentiment to drive ont sentiment^tbat is exotio, unwholesome, or "fanatioa1."
"FIGARO."

Commenting upon the White Paper npon Egypt, the "Figaro" hopes that certain French-men will gain knowledge by the deolaration of Egyptian Nationalists, whose propaganda is aided by events in Cairo and elsewhere. France is a Musa ulna an Power in Africa, and her cause being therefore that of England, she mast take the opinion of Lord Cromer. Prenob sympathy with Egyptian Nationalists is folly, and wonld, in the event of a con 11 tot, aid her adversaries.

div.head: POSTAL REFORM. AGREEMENT WITH GERMANY, BELGIUM, AND HOLLAND.
div.p: The "Dentsohe Woohetzeitong in den Niederlanden," a German weekly published in Amsterdam, learns that a special postal agreement has nearly been settled between Holland and its neighbours, Belgium, Germany, and England. According to this agreement, which is to oome into foroe on November 1st, 1907,the maximum weight of ordinary letters between Holland and eaoh of the three countries mentioned will be increased from fifteen to twenty grammes. Eogland, moreover, will secure the speoial advantage that its letters to Holland may weigh an English ounce. On the other hand, the postage rate between Holland and the three countries is to be reduced to 20 centimes, or 2d.

The joarnal adds that the delay in the final settlement resalts from minor details being still under discussion between Holland add England and Belgium, and between Holland and Germany. There will also be a redaction of postage rate) for newspapers, bat no details are given.

div.head: ANCIENT EGYPTIAN ARCHITECTURE.
div.p: Speaking on the snbjeot of Euglish archi-tecture at the International Congress of Ar-chitects at the Guildhall last week, the Dnke of Argyll said an American gentleman, who was once asked what it was that he liked best in the old country, replied "The seven lanoet windows of York Minster."

We must, however, acknowledge the debt which we owed to Italy in this respeot. We were also indebted to the older civilisations of Egypt and of Greeoe. It might be sarmised that with our noisy streets, motor-omnibuses, and traction-engines, we might have to go baok in oar domestio architecture to the Roman oonrts. He was sure that the only place where one oduld have a peaceable hoar's sleep at the present moment was the inside of a quadrilateral fortress. The Duke also alluded totlhe nee of steel in the oon- struotion of buildings, and concluded with another expres-ion of hearty weloome to the delegates.

div.head: A JERUSALEM DISCOVERY.
div.p: A remarkable arobm logical discovery is re-ported from Jerusalem. Some thirty years ago certain subterranean ohamhers near the Ecoe Homo Chapel, in the Via Dolorosa, were disoovered, but only partly explored, by Proffessor Clermont Ganneau, the famous ar cbicdogist. Recently the Greeks, while clearing out these ohamber', have disoovered others. Their researches point to these being anoient Roman rock-hewn prisons, similar to the well- known Latomiie of Syracuse, in Sioily.

In one of the newly disoovered chambers is a stone slab, about three feet high, containing a recess, while just above this recess, and oom munioating with it are two ciroalar holes, which were evidently meant to serve as stocks.

This ohamber has- bean converted into a chapel by the Greek monk*, and it has been visited by throngs of pilgrims, who firmly believe the holy site to be the aotual prison of Christ Among other discoveries in these rook- hewn prisons is a kind of oubliette below Christ's prison, which was fall of rubbish and human hones.—("Daily Mail.")
